title-group.article-title: Association between genetic polymorphism of the angiotensin-converting enzyme and diabetic nephropathy: a meta-analysis comprising 26,580 subjects

article-meta.aff: 1JiangSu Provincial Center for Disease Prevention and Control, Nanjing, China
2Department of Respiratory Medicine, Nanjing Children’s Hospital Affiliated to Nanjing Medical University, Nanjing, China

author-notes.corresp: Furu Wang, JiangSu Provincial Center for Disease Prevention and Control, 172 Jiangsu Road, Nanjing 210029, China. Email: wangfuru1983@126.com

fn.p: These authors contributed equally to this study.

abstract.p: Introduction: The effect of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) insertion/deletion (I/D) polymorphism on risk of diabetic nephropathy (DN) is still conflicting. The present meta-analysis was performed to evaluate the overall risk of this polymorphism associated with DN in different groups.
Materials and methods: A predefined search was performed on 14,108 DN cases and 12,472 controls from 63 published studies by searching electronic databases and reference lists of relevant articles.

Results: In this meta-analysis, we found a significant association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and the risk of DN for all genetic models (ID versus II: odds ratio [OR] = 1.12, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.02–1.24; DD versus II: OR = 1.27, 95% CI 1.13–1.44; allele contrast: OR = 1.15, 95% CI 1.08–1.23; dominant model: OR = 1.18, 95% CI 1.07–1.31; and recessive model: OR = 1.18, 95% CI 1.08–1.30, respectively). In stratified analysis by ethnicity and DM type, we further found that the Asian group with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) showed a significant association for all genetic models (ID versus II: OR = 1.25, 95% CI 1.07–1.47; DD versus II: OR = 1.57, 95% CI 1.24–1.98; allele contrast: OR = 1.30, 95% CI 1.15–1.46; dominant model: OR = 1.37, 95% CI 1.10–1.69; and recessive model: OR = 1.34, 95% CI 1.15–1.56, respectively).
Conclusions: Our study suggested that the ACE I/D polymorphism may contribute to DN development, especially in the Asian group with T2DM.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Diabetic nephropathy (DN) is a common and severe complication that occurs in ~40% of patients with a long-standing type II diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and in a lesser proportion of subjects with type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM),1 which is the largest single cause of end-stage renal disease (ESRD), and a medical catastrophe of worldwide dimensions.2 Abnormal microalbuminuria has emerged as a clinical risk factor for renal failure in diabetic renal disease as well as for cardiovascular disease in general and specifically in diabetes.3 However, albuminuria, elevated blood pressure and metabolic abnormalities only explain 30–50% of the variation in the progression of DN.4,5 Many factors including genetic parameters are thought to contribute to this complication.6 A familial clustering of DN indicated that a genetic predisposition is implicated in the pathogenesis of DN in both types of diabetes.7-11 Therefore, the etiology of DN is multifactorial and involves both environmental and genetic factors.12

The renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) has been strongly implicated in the pathogenesis of progressive renal disease.13 RAAS plays a central role in the regulation of blood pressure, sodium metabolism and renal hemodynamics, with its actions mediated primarily by angiotensin II. Angiotensin II is a powerful vasoconstrictor and intra-renal effects of the RAAS include changes in renal hemodynamics, such as an increase in intra-glomerular pressure as well as direct stimulation of mesangial cell proliferation and matrix production.14,15

The gene encoding components of the RAAS, such as angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), which seem to be particularly biologically and clinically relevant to renal disease, is the most widely studied of the candidate genes of the RAAS. Inhibitors of ACE are known to be more efficient than other antihypertensives in arresting the development of DN,16 the ACE gene has a frequent insertion–deletion (I/D) polymorphism (rs4344) characterized by the presence or absence of a 278 bp Alu repetitive sequence in intron 16 and the genotypes of this polymorphism were II, ID and DD. This polymorphism was associated with circulating ACE levels and increased plasma and tissue activity of this enzyme.17-19 Owing to the central role of the ACE gene in the RAAS, it is reasonable to hypothesize that genetic variation of ACE I/D contributes to the development of DN and numerous studies have addressed the role of the polymorphism in the complex etiology of DN.

A number of molecular epidemiological studies have been conducted to examine the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and DN,20-82 but the results remain inconsistent. Although several meta-analyses have been published in 1998 and 2005, they still have not reached a consistent conclusion. To estimate the overall risk of ACE I/D polymorphism associated with diabetic nephropathy and to quantify the potential between-study heterogeneity and to provide better power to detect smaller effect sizes, we conducted a comprehensive meta-analysis on 63 published studies from 1994 to 2010 with 14,108 DN cases and 12,472 controls relating variant of the ACE I/D to the risk of developing DN.

sec.title: Identification and eligibility of relevant studies
sec.p: We attempted to include all of the studies that determined the genotype distribution of ACE I/D polymorphism in cases with diabetes and nephropathy, and (i) in diseased controls (subjects with diabetes and free of DN) or (ii) in healthy controls in our meta-analysis. Cases were type 1 or 2 diabetic subjects with incipient (microalbuminuria) or advanced DN (proteinuria/macroalbuminuria, chronic renal failure, ESRD). The diseased control group consisted of subjects with diabetes and free of diabetic kidney disease, i.e. normoalbuminuria and normal renal function.

We first identified studies by searching the electronic literature PubMed for relevant reports (from January 1994 to December 2010, using the search terms ‘angiotensin converting enzyme and polymorphism and nephropathy’). We chose articles which were conducted among human subjects. Eligible studies were then identified by further searching the studies published to date on the association between ACE I/D polymorphism and DN risk and restricted attention to the studies that satisfied all of the following criteria: studies related to the ACE polymorphism were included regardless of study design (case–control, cross-sectional or cohort studies); each genotype frequency was reported, and there was sufficient information for the extraction of data; if studies had partly overlapped subjects, only the one with a larger and/or latest sample size was selected for the analysis. Additional studies were identified by hands-on searches from references of original studies or review articles on this topic (Figure 1). According to these criteria, we finally included 63 papers in our meta-analysis.

sec.title: Data extraction
sec.p: Two investigators independently extracted data and reached a consensus on all of the items. Data extracted from these articles included the first author’s name, year of publication, study design, ethnicity of the study population, type of diabetes mellitus, clinical characteristics, validity of the genotyping method and the number of cases and controls for ACE I/D genotypes. The frequencies of the alleles and the genotypic distributions were extracted or calculated for both cases and controls. In addition, it was tested whether the distribution of genotypes in the controls was consistent with Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium (HWE) for each study and calculated the frequency of the minor allele for ACE I/D polymorphism.

sec.title: Meta-analysis
sec.p: Our meta-analysis examined the association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and the risk of DN for each study by odds ratio (OR) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). For all studies, we calculated the ORs for (i) the separate pairwise comparisons, (ii) the allele contrast, (iii) the dominant model and (iv) the recessive model. In addition, we conducted stratification analysis by ethnicity and DM type. A sensitivity analysis, which examines the effect of excluding specific studies, was also performed.83 Our meta-analysis was subjected to sensitivity analysis for studies with the controls not in HWE (p < 0.05).

The χ2-based Q statistic test was used for the assessment of heterogeneity, and it was considered significant for p < 0.05. Heterogeneity was quantified with the I2 metric, which is independent of the number of studies in the meta-analysis. The I2 metric takes values between 0 and 100%, with higher values denoting greater a degree of heterogeneity (I2 > 50% was considered significant).84 We used the fixed-effects model and the random-effects model based on the Mantel–Haenszel method and the DerSimonian and Laird method, respectively, to combine values from each of the studies. When the effects were assumed to be homogenous, the fixed-effects model was then used; otherwise, the random-effects model was more appropriate. In addition, we further evaluated the source of heterogeneity by conducting meta-regression analyses. Publication bias was assessed according to the Egger regression asymmetry test and the Begg adjusted rank correlation test.85,86 All analyses were performed by using the Statistical Analysis System software (v.9.1.3, SAS Institute, Cary, NC) and Stata soft (v.11.0). All of the p-values were two-sided.

sec.title: Eligible studies and study characteristics
sec.p: The selected study characteristics from the studies included in the meta-analysis are provided in Table 1. In all studies, valid genotyping methods were used: polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and restriction of the PCR product with the corresponding enzyme or PCR with allele-specific probes, and electrophoretic differentiation. A total of 22 studies (19 White, 3 Asian) involved cases with T1DM and 42 (15 White, 27 Asian) with T2DM. The studies on T1DM Whites contributed 3,036 cases and 3,475 control subjects, while the Asian studies included 181 cases and 141 control subjects. Among the T2DM studies, studies involving Whites contributed 5,370 cases and 3,727 control subjects, while the Asian studies included 5,521 cases and 5,129 control subjects. A total of 32 studies used a case–control study design, 24 studies used a cross-sectional study design, and 7 studies used a cohort study design.

caption.p: Characteristics of published studies included in the meta-analysis.

fn.p: # Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium (HWE) test and *the minor allele frequency (MAF) were calculated in control group for each study. NR, not reported; NA, not available; DM, diabetes mellitus; CC, case–control; CS, cross-sectional; CH, cohort; Normo, nonrmoalbuminuria; Micro, microalbuminuria; Prot, proteinuria; Macro, macroalbuminuria; CRF, chronic renal failure; ESRD, end-stage renal disease; HD, hemodialysis; DM, diabetes mellitus.

sec.title: Summary statistics
sec.p: Data from 63 articles that investigated the association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and DN were included in the meta-analysis. The overall frequency (%) of minor A allele frequency (MAF) was 0.50/0.47 for cases and controls. The frequency of the MAF for each individual study polymorphism for controls is given in Table 1.

All studies indicated that the distribution of genotypes in the controls was consistent with Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium except for nine studies,25,27,38,41,55,64,69,75,77 indicating genotyping errors and/or population stratification;83 therefore, a sensitivity analysis was performed excluding these studies.

sec.title: Main results, stratification, and sensitivity analyses
sec.p: The evaluations of the association of ACE I/D polymorphism with DN are presented in Table 2. Figure 2 shows the overall and subgroup results for the association between the polymorphism and the risk of DN (in the dominant model).

caption.p: Summary odds ratios (ORs) and heterogeneity results for associations between the ACE I/D polymorphism and diabetic nephropathy.

fn.p: Test for heterogeneity. A random-effects model was used when the p-value for heterogeneity test < 0.05 and/or I2 > 50%; otherwise, a fixed-effects model was used.

caption.p: Odds ratios (log scale) of diabetic nephropathy associated with ACE I/D polymorphism for dominant genetic model. The graph shows individual and pooled estimates for all studies, and studies on type 1 diabetic Whites and Asians, as well as Whites and Asians with type 2 diabetes.

sec.p: As shown in Table 2, the overall analysis detected a significant association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and the risk of DN for all genetic models (ID versus II: OR = 1.12, 95% CI 1.02–1.24; DD versus II: OR = 1.27, 95% CI 1.13–1.44; allele contrast: OR = 1.15, 95% CI 1.08–1.23; dominant model: OR = 1.18, 95% CI 1.07–1.31; and recessive model: OR = 1.18, 95% CI 1.08–1.30, respectively).

In stratified analysis by ethnicity and diabetes mellitus type, we further found that the Asian group with T2DM showed a significant association for all genetic models (ID versus II: OR = 1.25, 95% CI 1.07–1.47; DD versus II: OR = 1.57, 95% CI 1.24–1.98; allele contrast: OR = 1.30, 95% CI 1.15–1.46; dominant model: OR = 1.37, 95% CI 1.10–1.69; and recessive model: OR = 1.34, 95% CI 1.15–1.56, respectively). However, we failed to find any significant effects for different genetic models in other subgroup. Further sensitivity analysis for HWE did not alter the pattern of results in both overall analysis and subgroup analysis.

sec.title: Source of heterogeneity and publication bias
sec.p: As shown in Table 2, heterogeneity between studies was observed in overall comparisons as well as subgroup analyses. We evaluated the source of heterogeneity in both dominant and recessive genetic models of the variant allele by ethnicity (Asian or White), DM type (T1DM or T2DM), HWE (in HWE or not) and study design (case–control, cross-sectional or cohort study design) by meta-regression analyses. It revealed that none of these five factors could explain significant between-study heterogeneity in genetic model for the polymorphism ACE I/D: ethnicity (p = 0.09), DM type (p = 0.77), HWE (p = 0.58) and study design (p = 0.82).

The potential presence of publication bias was evaluated using a funnel plot of the estimate of log-OR for the genotype DD versus II+ ID against the reciprocal of its standard error (Figure 3). As is shown, no significant funnel asymmetry was observed which could indicate publication bias. We further used the Egger regression asymmetry test and the Begg adjusted rank correlation tests to access the publication bias of included literatures in the meta-analysis. As shown in Table 3, no publication bias was observed for the polymorphism and risk of DN in the genetic model.

caption.p: Evaluation of publication bias using funnel plots. Plots are shown for all studies (A), subgroups involving type 1 diabetic Whites (B), and Whites and Asians with type 2 diabetes (C, D). No significant funnel asymmetry was observed which could indicate publication bias.
The results of the publication bias test in the dominant genetic model by Egger test and Begg test.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Why some diabetics develop nephropathy, whereas others do not, despite having a long-term hyperglycemia, remains an unresolved question. Because known environmental factors do not fully explain this, researchers have sought the answer in the genetic background of the host.56 The RAAS is a critical regulator of sodium balance, extracellular fluid volume, vascular resistance, and, ultimately, arterial blood pressure by angiotensin II. Thus, the RAAS serves as one of the most powerful regulators of arterial blood pressure and could be considered candidate genes involved in the pathogenesis of diabetic renal complication.87 The ACE is an important part of the RAAS, which is a complex regulatory network with intrinsic as well as extrinsic agonistic and antagonistic hormones. It had increasingly been recognized that ACE inhibition exert organ protective effects probably even beyond its antihypertensive potential in diabetic renal disease.88,89 In 1990, Rigat et al.19 described the polymorphism of the ACE gene based on the presence (insertion I) or absence (deletion D) of a 278 base pair element in intron 16. Although the results of DNA gel-blot hybridization indicate that the insertion/deletion polymorphism is localized in the non-coding region (intron), it cannot exclude the possibility that as a result of different ACE pre-mRNA splicing, depending on the presence or absence of the insertion, part of this sequence might be present in the mature RNA, thus modifying its stability or giving rise to the presence of an additional peptide inside the protein, and consequently altering its secretion or stability. In addition, the insertion itself might modify the splicing process of the ACE precursor mRNA by interfering with the lariat formation step.90 This genotype accounts for 47% of the total phenotypic variance in plasma ACE levels in healthy individuals in a way that subjects with D alleles have an elevated activity.19 In addition Danser et al.91 showed that the ACE I/D polymorphism also influences ACE tissue concentrations. Numerous investigations into the potential role of ACE as a susceptibility gene for DN have been conducted over the past decades, with controversial results. Early meta-analyses attempted to reconcile these findings, but attempts to draw firm conclusions have been hindered by limited data, particularly when examining specific patient subgroups and increased relative studies.92-94 From the present meta-analysis of 63 studies reported from 1994 to 2010 and comprising 26,580 subjects, we further found significant main effects and subgroup effects for ACE I/D polymorphism on DN risk, especially in the Asian group with T2DM.

Our meta-analysis examined the ACE I/D polymorphism and its relationship to susceptibility for DN. Its strength was based on the accumulation of published data giving greater information to detect significant differences. Non-English, non-indexed, and non-published studies in the literature were not reviewed, and this might introduce some bias.95 In this study, the effect of separate pairwise comparisons, allele contrast and the effects of the dominant and recessive genetic models were estimated. Subgroup analysis by ethnicity and DM type, and sensitivity for studies not in HWE, was performed. In addition, we further evaluated the source of heterogeneity and the publication bias of included literatures.

In the meta-analysis, only the unadjusted pooled ORs were calculated, because data for possible confounding factors that influence the estimates of associations (e.g. age, sex, body mass index [BMI]) were not provided. Sampling variability and stratification in genetic association studies could be a possible confounding factor on the role of genetic markers. In addition, the risk effect may depend on the interaction with other risk factors: smoking, alcohol consumption, exercise, control of diabetes, and BMI, all of which modulate the development of DN.96,97 Furthermore, small numbers of individuals and inadequate information of lifestyle factors and dietary intake by the published studies limited our statistic power to fully investigate the gene–environment interactions. Therefore, further well-designed large studies, particularly referring to gene–gene and gene–environment interactions are warranted to confirm the real contribution of the ACE I/D polymorphism to DN susceptibility and might further elucidate the genetics of DN.

In summary, our present meta-analysis demonstrated that the ACE I/D polymorphism was associated with DN, especially in the Asian group with T2DM. ACE inhibitors are already widely used in the clinical management of DN. Studies have examined how the effect of these drugs on DN can be modulated by genetic variation at the ACE locus. Several studies have indicated that the DD genotype could be associated with better response to the anti-proteinuric effect of ACE inhibitors in patients with DN. Our present analysis not only might help us to further explore whether and how the ACE I/D polymorphism mutation play its own role in the development of DN, but also help us to make more effectively targeted use of ACE inhibitors in the clinical management of DN.

ack.p: The authors would like to gratefully acknowledge the most helpful comments on this paper received from Professor Yong Gu, Division of Nephrology, Huashan Hospital and Institute of Nephrology, Fudan University, China.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding age in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest.
